response.name: Kyamoneka Mpey Benjamin
response.title: Human Rights Defender | Privacy First Campaigner at Amnesty International
response.tagline: Empowering Youth. Defending Rights. Inspiring Change.
response.quote: Human rights are not a privilege conferred by the state. They are every human being's entitlement by virtue of their humanity.
response.education: Law Student at Mount Kenya University – School of Law
response.bio:
I am a Congolese law student at Mount Kenya University – School of Law, with a passion for justice, human rights, and environmental sustainability. My advocacy focuses on climate action, digital rights, gender equality, anti-corruption, and legal empowerment.

Currently, I serve as a Campaign Advocate at Amnesty International Kenya, supporting the Privacy First Campaign. My leadership roles include Managing Partner at Legal Alliance Associates where I've trained 114+ law students, Country Director (DRC) of The Lawrit Journal of Law promoting legal research and youth engagement, Red Card Ambassador with ARDN advocating against gender-based violence, and President & Co-Founder of EDDEC where I led a 6,000-tree afforestation project in Goma.

I'm an alumnus of Venice School of Human Rights Defenders (2025), Global Campus of Human Rights, Global Youth Climate Leadership Programme at University of Oxford, and International Anti-Corruption Academy in partnership with UNODC.

Selected as a 2025 Youth Delegate for You(th) Rebuilding the Broken in Belgium (July 31–Aug 3) and HISA Youth Fellowship in Oxford, UK (Aug 23–26).
response.mission: To advance justice, equity, and sustainability through human rights advocacy, legal empowerment, and youth engagement.
response.vision: A world where human rights, environmental justice, and digital privacy are protected for all, with youth recognized as powerful agents of change.

response.name: Kyamoneka Mpey Benjamin
response.title: Défenseur des Droits Humains | Militant Privacy First chez Amnesty International
response.tagline: Autonomiser la Jeunesse. Défendre les Droits. Inspirer le Changement.
response.quote: Les droits humains ne sont pas un privilège accordé par l'État. Ils sont le droit de chaque être humain en vertu de son humanité.
response.education: Étudiant en Droit à l'Université Mount Kenya – École de Droit
response.bio:
Je suis un étudiant congolais en droit à l'Université Mount Kenya – École de Droit, passionné par la justice, les droits humains et la durabilité environnementale. Mon plaidoyer se concentre sur l'action climatique, les droits numériques, l'égalité des sexes, la lutte contre la corruption et l'autonomisation juridique.

Actuellement, je sers comme Défenseur de Campagne chez Amnesty International Kenya, soutenant la Campagne Privacy First. Mes rôles de leadership incluent Associé Gérant chez Legal Alliance Associates où j'ai formé plus de 114 étudiants en droit, Directeur National (RDC) du Journal Lawrit of Law promouvant la recherche juridique et l'engagement des jeunes, Ambassadeur Red Card avec ARDN plaidant contre la violence basée sur le genre, et Président & Co-fondateur d'EDDEC où j'ai dirigé un projet de reboisement de 6 000 arbres à Goma.
focus_areas: Droits à la Vie Privée Numérique
response.mission: Faire progresser la justice, l'équité et la durabilité grâce au plaidoyer des droits humains, à l'autonomisation juridique et à l'engagement des jeunes.
response.vision: Un monde où les droits humains, la justice environnementale et la vie privée numérique sont protégés pour tous, avec les jeunes reconnus comme des agents puissants du changement.

response.name: كياموناكا مباي بنجامين
response.title: مدافع عن حقوق الإنسان | ناشط الخصوصية أولاً في منظمة العفو الدولية
response.tagline: تمكين الشباب. الدفاع عن الحقوق. إلهام التغيير.
response.quote: حقوق الإنسان ليست امتيازاً تمنحه الدولة. إنها حق كل إنسان بحكم إنسانيته.
response.education: طالب قانون في جامعة جبل كينيا - كلية الحقوق
response.bio:
أنا طالب قانون كونغولي في جامعة جبل كينيا - كلية الحقوق، لدي شغف بالعدالة وحقوق الإنسان والاستدامة البيئية. يركز عملي على العمل المناخي والحقوق الرقمية والمساواة بين الجنسين ومكافحة الفساد والتمكين القانوني.

حالياً، أعمل كمدافع عن الحملات في منظمة العفو الدولية كينيا، ودعم حملة الخصوصية أولاً. تشمل أدواري القيادية الشريك الإداري في تحالف المساعدين القانونيين حيث دربت أكثر من 114 طالب قانون، والمدير القطري (جمهورية الكونغو الديمقراطية) لمجلة لوريت للقانون الترويج للبحث القانوني ومشاركة الشباب.
response.mission: تعزيز العدالة والإنصاف والاستدامة من خلال الدفاع عن حقوق الإنسان والتمكين القانوني ومشاركة الشباب.
response.vision: عالم تُحمى فيه حقوق الإنسان والعدالة البيئية والخصوصية الرقمية للجميع، مع الاعتراف بالشباب كعوامل قوية للتغيير.

response.name: 基亚蒙奈卡·姆派·本杰明
response.title: 人权捍卫者 | 国际特赦组织隐私优先活动家
response.tagline: 赋能青年。捍卫权利。启发变革。
response.quote: 人权不是国家赋予的特权。它们是每个人凭借其人性应有的权利。
response.education: 肯尼亚山大学法学院法学学生
response.bio:
我是肯尼亚山大学法学院的刚果法学学生，对正义、人权和环境可持续性充满热情。我的倡导重点是气候行动、数字权利、性别平等、反腐败和法律赋权。

目前，我在国际特赦组织肯尼亚分部担任活动倡导者，支持隐私优先活动。我的领导角色包括法律联盟合伙人管理合伙人，在那里我培训了114多名法学学生，Lawrit法律杂志国家主任（刚果民主共和国）促进法律研究和青年参与，ARDN红牌大使倡导反对基于性别的暴力，以及EDDEC总裁兼联合创始人，我在戈马领导了6000棵树的造林项目。
response.mission: 通过人权倡导、法律赋权和青年参与推进正义、公平和可持续性。
response.vision: 一个人权、环境正义和数字隐私得到保护的世界，青年被认为是变革的强大推动者。

response.name: Kyamoneka Mpey Benjamin
response.title: Defensor de Derechos Humanos | Activista Privacidad Primero en Amnistía Internacional
response.tagline: Empoderando Jóvenes. Defendiendo Derechos. Inspirando Cambio.
response.quote: Los derechos humanos no son un privilegio otorgado por el estado. Son el derecho de cada ser humano en virtud de su humanidad.
response.education: Estudiante de Derecho en Universidad Mount Kenya – Escuela de Derecho
response.bio:
Soy un estudiante de derecho congoleño en la Universidad Mount Kenya – Escuela de Derecho, con pasión por la justicia, los derechos humanos y la sostenibilidad ambiental. Mi activismo se enfoca en acción climática, derechos digitales, igualdad de género, anticorrupción y empoderamiento legal.

Actualmente, sirvo como Defensor de Campaña en Amnistía Internacional Kenia, apoyando la Campaña Privacidad Primero. Mis roles de liderazgo incluyen Socio Gerente en Legal Alliance Associates donde he entrenado a más de 114 estudiantes de derecho, Director Nacional (RDC) de The Lawrit Journal of Law promoviendo investigación legal y participación juvenil, Embajador Tarjeta Roja con ARDN abogando contra la violencia basada en género, y Presidente y Co-fundador de EDDEC donde lideré un proyecto de forestación de 6,000 árboles en Goma.
response.mission: Avanzar la justicia, equidad y sostenibilidad a través de la defensa de derechos humanos, empoderamiento legal y participación juvenil.
response.vision: Un mundo donde los derechos humanos, la justicia ambiental y la privacidad digital están protegidos para todos, con los jóvenes reconocidos como agentes poderosos de cambio.

response.author: Benjamin Kyamoneka Mpey

response.title: From Streets to Screens: How Kenyan Gen Z Protests Against the Finance Bill Sparked a Pan-African Youth Movement
response.content:
Introduction
Imagine a generation born into a world of digital connectivity, yet disconnected from the opportunities it promised. In June 2023, Kenya's Gen Z young, restless, and relentless, took to the streets to defy a government that sought to impose a tax bill threatening their already fragile livelihoods. This was not just another protest; it was a youth-led revolution. With smartphones as their weapons and hashtags as their battle cries, they shook the foundations of power in Kenya and, in the process, sparked a fire of activism across Africa. From Nairobi to Lagos, from Cape Town to Kampala, Africa's youth were awakened, their voices now louder than ever. The message was clear: the time for passive acceptance was over, and the future of Africa belonged to its boldest generation yet.

In the middle of the year 2024, exactly on June 1, 2024, Kenya was shaken by widespread protests against the controversial Finance Bill 2024, a legislation that proposed increased taxes on fuel, housing, and digital content. The bill, part of President William Ruto's government's plan to raise revenue, was met with fierce opposition, especially from the country's youth.
response.excerpt: Exploring how Kenya's Gen Z protests against the 2024 Finance Bill ignited a continent-wide youth movement, demonstrating the power of digital activism and cross-border solidarity in modern Africa.
response.author: Benjamin Kyamoneka Mpey

response.title: From Political Domination to Economic Subjugation: Assessing the Impacts of International Financial Institutions on African Sovereignty
response.content:
Introduction
In 1983, tens of thousands of Zambians took to the streets in mass protests against the 1983 Agreement, a policy enforced under the structural adjustments programs (SAPs) of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank that involved among other things the devaluation of currency, decontrol of prices of essential commodities and the removal of subsidies on maize and fertilisers. Similarly, in 2024, Kenya was rocked by nationwide protests against the proposed 2024/2025 Finance Bill, which introduced steep tax hikes on basic commodities. For millions of Kenyans, already grappling with the rising cost of living, these measures were a direct assault to their livelihoods. The government, however, defended the bill as necessary to meet the stringent fiscal targets set by international lenders like the IMF, whose support was critical to Kenya's mounting debt crisis. Both of these scenes, not only encapsulate the complexities of Africa's economic journey, a journey shaped by both the pull of global agendas and the push for self-determination on the continent, but also echoe a deeper narrative across Africa: the persistent challenge of balancing the demands of global financial institutions with their own aspirations for sovereignty and sustainable development.
response.excerpt: A critical analysis of how IMF and World Bank policies impact African sovereignty and sustainable development, examining the tension between global financial institutions and national self-determination.
response.author: Benjamin Kyamoneka Mpey

response.title: The Legal Obligation of the State in Addressing Climate Change-Induced Disasters in the Global South
response.content:
Introduction
Over the past three decades, in a changing world threatened by annihilation, humanity has negotiated to stabilize greenhouse gases for the survival of both present and future generations. Under the UN's patronage, states concluded agreements, including the UNFCCC and Paris Agreement, based on the core principle of common but differentiated responsibilities concerning climate-induced disasters, as enshrined under Article 3(1) of the UNFCCC. This principle, on one hand, underscores that developing countries, especially in the Global South, are entitled to differentiated responsibilities when addressing climate change disasters, owing to historical inequities in contribution to global emissions. As a matter of fact, according to the IPCC, climate change disproportionately impacts developing nations, with over 1 billion people expected to face acute food insecurity by 2050 due to climate-related challenges. On the other hand, it opines that developed nations, having historically contributed more to climate change, bear a greater burden in terms of mitigation and support. The two aforementioned agreements underscore the urgency for all nations, especially developed ones, to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and assist developing countries, which bear the disproportionate effects of climate-induced disasters such as cyclones, droughts, and floods.
response.excerpt: Examining the legal obligations of Global South states in addressing climate change-induced disasters while balancing human rights protection and indigenous peoples' rights.
response.author: Benjamin Kyamoneka Mpey

response.title: The Role of the Intellectual Property in Attaining the SDGs through Creativity and Innovation
response.content:
Introduction
In the face of a threat of annihilation due to climate change, in the past few decades, going from Tokyo to Rio, from Rio to Paris and from Paris to Baku, States and Non-States Actors engaged into various negotiations aimed at promoting sustainable development. The concept of Sustainable Development was defined in the Brundtland report of 1987 titled "Our Common Future" as a form of development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. At the Earth Summit held in Rio de Janeiro in June 1992, Sustainable Development was recognized and subsequently translated into a series of agreements, including the Paris Agreement of 2015. In September 2015, the United Nations adopted 17 goals of Sustainable Development as part of its 2030 Agenda. In 2023, the United Nations Economic and Social Council in its report noted that at the midpoint to 2030, global progress on SDGs remain uneven and the world is not even on track to achieve SDGs. According to the WTO, Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) are the rights given to persons over the creations of their minds. Their origins can be traced to the need for individuals and societies to foster creativity and innovation. However, despite its ability to drive change through creativity and innovation, the IP has been understated within various international agreements. In this regard, considering the urgency of attaining SDGs, this essay firstly elaborates on the types of IPRs and their legal regimes, secondly it demonstrates the critical role of IP in attaining SDGs through the reduction of inequalities, promotion of innovation, creation of jobs and alleviation of poverty. Lastly, it tackles commercialization and enforcement challenges of IPRs.
response.excerpt: An in-depth analysis of how Intellectual Property Rights serve as catalysts for achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals through creativity, innovation, and economic empowerment.
response.author: Benjamin Kyamoneka Mpey
